required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Efficacy of Maitland Mobilization in Shoulder Pathology
clinical_study.official_title: Effec of Maitland in Shoulder Pathology

lead_sponsor.agency: University of Las Palmas de Gran Canaria

clinical_study.source: University of Las Palmas de Gran Canaria

brief_summary.textblock: The shoulder is a mobile structure which generates a lot of pathologies. One of them is rotator cuff tendinosis. On the other hand, it has been investigated that Maitland is effective for reducing pain and for mobility in the cervical and lumbar spine and in joints such as the knee and ankle, however, there are few studies that confirm that it is effective in shoulder pathologies.So here the investigatprs want to study the effectiveness of Maitland as an adjunctive treatment for shoulder pathologies, comparing it with conventional physiotherapy treatment, in relation to the reduction of pain and increased mobility. For that the investigators have a randomized clinical trial with two group.

detailed_description.textblock: Group 1 receives tens, SW, conventional physiotherapy and exercises as treatment. Group 2 receives tens, SW, Mailtland, and exercises. An assessment is carried out at the beginning of the treatment, at the end and 2-4 weeks after finishing the treatment. The EVA ASES, DASH and SF-36 scales are included and the biomechanics study is used for the range of mobility.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 1, 5, and 7 weeks after treatment
primary_outcome.description: Active ROM of the affected shoulder is measured using a Mechanic Analysis to assess range of motion. These measurements included abduction, flexion, internal rotation, and external rotation.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 1, 5, and 7 weeks after treatment
primary_outcome.description: Visual analogue score (VAS) was done at rest and at shoulder movement. VAS was explained to the patients during assessment as 0 equal no pain and 10 equal worst imaginable pain.

primary_outcome.measure: Change of Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 1, 5, and 7 weeks after treatment
primary_outcome.description: Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) was filled by patient during assessment as 0 equal better functionality and 100 equal worst functionality

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of American shoulder and elbow Surgeons" (ASES)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 1, 5, and 7 weeks after treatment
secondary_outcome.description: Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) was filled by patient during assessment as 0 equal worst functionality and 100 is equal better functionality

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 1, 5, and 7 weeks after treatment
secondary_outcome.description: Health Survey (SF-36) was filled by patient during assessment as 0 equal worst health and 100 is equal better health

arm_group.description: 44 patients receives tens, SW, Maitland, and exercises. An assessment is carried out at the beginning of the treatment, at the end and 2-4 weeks after finishing the treatment. The EVA ASES, DASH and SF-36 scales are included and the biomechanics study is used for the range of mobility.

44 receives tens, SW, conventional physiotherapy and exercises as treatment. An assessment is carried out at the beginning of the treatment, at the end and 2-4 weeks after finishing the treatment. The EVA ASES, DASH and SF-36 scales are included and the biomechanics study is used for the range of mobility.

intervention.description: An assessment is carried out at the beginning of the treatment, at the end and 2-4 weeks after finishing the treatment. The EVA ASES, DASH and SF-36 scales are included and the biomechanics study is used for the range of mobility.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Have a shoulder pathology.
- Have a restriction at least of two ranges of movement of the shoulder.
- Sign the consent before starting the study.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients with a history of shoulder or neck surgery.
- Patients with neurological damage such as stroke or disease of Parkinson's, as well as those with rheumatism, osteoporosis, surgical fixation, or malignant tumors.
- Have a radiating pain in shoulder from a cervical injury.
- Pregnant patients.
- Patients who do not sign the consent before starting the study.
